### Problem Description:
You're customizing a gaming laptop by selecting a CPU, GPU, and a cooling system.
Each component has a performance rating, and your goal is to maximize performance
without violating thermal constraints.
You can pick from:
CPUs: Ryzen9, i7, or M1.
GPUs: RTX3070, RX6700XT, and IrisXe.
Cooling systems: AirCool, LiquidCool, and PassiveCool.

Performance matters — the faster the CPU and GPU, the better. But cooling must be
sufficient:
LiquidCool is required for high-performance parts like Ryzen9 or RTX3070.
PassiveCool is insufficient for discrete GPUs.
M1 chips are low-heat and can use PassiveCool.
RX6700XT is incompatible with M1.

Performance scores:
Ryzen9: 95, i7: 85, M1: 70
RTX3070: 90, RX6700XT: 88, IrisXe: 65
AirCool: 20, LiquidCool: 40, PassiveCool: 5
Implement: Each configuration selects one CPU, one GPU, one cooler.

1 { selected_cpu(C) : cpu(C, _) } 1.
1 { selected_gpu(G) : gpu(G, _) } 1.
1 { selected_cooler(C) : cooler(C, _) } 1.
Implement: LiquidCool is required for high-performance parts.

:- selected_cpu(C), high_perf(C), selected_cooler(K), K != "LiquidCool".
:- selected_gpu(G), high_perf(G), selected_cooler(K), K != "LiquidCool".
Implement: PassiveCool is not allowed with discrete GPUs.

total_perf(P) :-
selected_cpu(C), cpu(C, P1),
selected_gpu(G), gpu(G, P2),
selected_cooler(K), cooler(K, P3),
P = P1 + P2 + P3.
#maximize { P : total_perf(P) }.

### Problem Description:
You are configuring a drone for a delivery service. You must choose a frame, motor
type, and battery.
The drone’s flight endurance is the primary metric, and you want to maximize it while
ensuring that power and weight constraints are satisfied.
Available options:
    Frames: Lightweight, Standard, Reinforced
    Motors: Eco, Standard, HighTorque
    Batteries: SmallCell, MediumCell, LongLife
Constraints:
    Lightweight frames can’t handle HighTorque motors.
    Reinforced frames are required for LongLife batteries.
    HighTorque motors draw more power and require LongLife batteries.
    SmallCell batteries can only power Eco motors.
    MediumCell batteries are compatible with Eco or Standard motors.
Endurance scores:
    Lightweight: 50, Standard: 40, Reinforced: 30
    Eco: 60, Standard: 70, HighTorque: 90
    SmallCell: 30, MediumCell: 50, LongLife: 80
Implement: Select one frame, one motor, one battery

1 { selected_frame(F) : frame(F, _) } 1.
1 { selected_motor(M) : motor(M, _) } 1.
1 { selected_battery(B) : battery(B, _) } 1.
Implement: Lightweight frame is incompatible with HighTorque motor.
Implement: LongLife battery requires Reinforced frame
Implement: SmallCell battery only works with Eco motor.
Implement: MediumCell battery supports only Eco or Standard motor

total_endurance(E) :-
selected_frame(F), frame(F, EF),
selected_motor(M), motor(M, EM),
selected_battery(B), battery(B, EB),
E = EF + EM + EB.
#maximize { E : total_endurance(E) }.

You are an expert AI researcher. Translate the following problem description into syntactically correct Clingo ASP code step-by-step.

### Problem Description:
A marine survey drone emerges from SubDock into a labyrinth of 
undersea currents that define a bidirectional routing graph. 
Each current lane exacts a heat load on the drone’s systems rather than 
battery measured in heat units and all traversals take one time unit. 
The drone starts with a maximum heat tolerance of 10 units; every movement 
along a lane adds its heat load, and it can shed all heat by lingering in 
a cool-water eddy at NodeX for two consecutive minutes.
From SubDock, the drone may navigate the gentle CoralPass (2 units) or the 
turbulent VentStream (4 units). CoralPass leads to BeaconAlpha (1 unit) or 
loops via DeepLoop (1 unit) back to VentStream. VentStream leads directly 
to BeaconBeta (2 units) or to a sensor hub NodeX (1 unit), which branches 
to BeaconGamma (3 units). BeaconGamma also offers a strong down‑draft 
conduit back to BeaconAlpha (4 units).
At each beacon the drone can perform an acoustic pulse that 
requires 2 minutes and raises heat by 1 unit for data calibration. The 
mission mandates pulses at BeaconAlpha and BeaconBeta. BeaconAlpha must be 
pulsed before minute 5. BeaconGamma is optional but must be pulsed iff all 
mandatory pulses are finised within 8 minutes.
No more than 16 total actions (moves, pulses, cooldowns) are permitted. 
If NodeX is entered, the drone must either pulse there immediately or 
perform a cooldown before moving on. Movements and pulses cannot exceed the 
heat tolerance at any time. Consecutive pulses without reconfiguring at the VentStream
are forbidden to avoid signal overlap. The aim which is primary in choosing one 
of multiple possibe routes must be to avoid wasting time, that is time at which the
drone is not performing an acoustic pulse at any survey location.
Implement: Nodes: SubDock, CoralPass, VentStream, BeaconAlpha, DeepLoop, BeaconBeta, NodeX, BeaconGamma.

edge("SubDock","CoralPass",2).
edge("SubDock","VentStream",4).
edge("CoralPass","BeaconAlpha",1).
edge("CoralPass","DeepLoop",1).
edge("DeepLoop","VentStream",1).
edge("VentStream","BeaconBeta",2).
edge("VentStream","NodeX",1).
edge("NodeX","BeaconGamma",3).
edge("BeaconGamma","BeaconAlpha",4).
Implement: Movement takes 1 min, heat increases per edge.

time(0..15).
1{ at(L, T): loc(L) }1 :- time(T).
:- at(L1, T), at(L2, T+1), not edge(L1, L2, _), not edge(L2, L1, _), L1 != L2.
heat(T+1,H2) :- at(L1,T), at(L2,T+1), edge(L1,L2,Cost), heat(T,H1), H2=H1+Cost.
Implement: Scans take 2 minutes and increase heat by 1.

at(L,T)        :- pulse_at(L,T).
at(L,T+1)      :- pulse_at(L,T), T < 15.
heat(T+2,H+1)   :- pulse_at(_,T), heat(T,H), T < 14.
Implement: Pulsing at BeaconAlpha & BeaconBeta is mandatory, BeaconGamma optional.
Implement: BeaconAlpha must be pulsed by time 5.
Implement: Pulse BeaconGamma iff mandatory pulses finish by minute 8.

mand_done :- pulse_at("BeaconAlpha",TA), pulse_at("BeaconBeta",TB), max(TA,TB) <= 8.
:- pulse_at("BeaconGamma",_), not mand_done.
:- mand_done, not pulse_at("BeaconGamma",_).
Implement: Cooldown: stop at NodeX for 2 min and reduce heat to 0.

cooldown(T) :- at("NodeX",T), at("NodeX",T+1), T < 15.
heat(T+2,0) :- cooldown(T), T < 14.
Implement: When at NodeX next action must be either pulse at NodeX or cooldown.
:- at("NodeX",T), T < 15, not cooldown(T), not pulse_at(_,T+1).

action(T)   :- at(L1, T), at(L2, T+1), L1 != L2.
action(T)   :- pulse_at(_,T).
action(T) :- cooldown(T).
:- #count {A : action(A)} > 16.
Implement: Must visit VentStream between each pulsing.

vent_between(L, H) :-  at("VentStream",T), L < T < H, time(L), time(H).
:- pulse_at(_,T1), pulse_at(_,T2), not vent_between(T1, T2), T1 < T2.
Implement: Objective: minimise time in which not pulsing.

non_pulse(T) :- time(T), not pulse_at(_,T).
non_pulses(N) :- N = #count{ T: non_pulse(T) }.
#minimize { N: non_pulses(N) }.

### Problem Description:
You are assembling a basic custom PC build using three components: a CPU, a GPU, and a motherboard.
There are two options for each component type:
CPUs: Ryzen5 or i5
GPUs: GTX1660 or RX580
Motherboards: B450 or Z390
Each final build must include exactly one CPU, one GPU, and one motherboard.
However, there are compatibility rules:
The Ryzen5 CPU is only compatible with the B450 motherboard.
The i5 CPU is only compatible with the Z390 motherboard.
The RX580 GPU is not compatible with the Z390 motherboard.
You must select a valid combination of components that satisfies all compatibility constraints.
Implement: Select exactly one CPU from {Ryzen5, i5}.
Implement: Select exactly one GPU from {GTX1660, RX580}.
Implement: Select exactly one motherboard from {B450, Z390}.
Implement: The Ryzen5 CPU requires the B450 motherboard.
Implement: The i5 CPU requires the Z390 motherboard.
Implement: The RX580 GPU is incompatible with the Z390 motherboard.

### Problem Description:
When preparing a workstation tailored for data-intensive simulations, you’re expected to
select a processor, a graphics card, and a storage unit from a shortlist provided by the
procurement office. Each category contains exactly three items, all of which vary in
cost and advertised performance ratings. While only one item from each class can be
chosen, it's not as simple as picking the best in each—certain budgetary and performance
considerations are in play.
Let’s start with the CPUs: the X9 offers moderate speed (score 95) for $300, the ZetaCore is the
highest-performing chip (score 120) and costs $500, and the Alpha8, while slightly below
ZetaCore in speed (score 110), still carries a premium at $450. Meanwhile, your GPU choices
include QuasarRTX (130 points, $700), NovaX (125 points, $600), and the more modest GammaGTX
(90 points, $450). For storage, there’s UltraSSD (100 points, $250), FusionDrive (95 points,
$300), and the budget-tier MegaHDD (60 points, $200).
One of the directives from IT leadership is that your most costly component must also be
the one delivering the greatest performance in your final selection—presumably to justify
budget overruns. However, it's frowned upon to pick the single highest-rated part from each
of the three categories; evidently, they want to avoid over-spec’d builds. There’s also a
guideline about balance: while you don’t need to match prices perfectly, no component
should differ in cost from another by more than $250. Consider that a soft constraint, they'll
reject your build if that balance is off.
Also, while the graphics team claims that a powerful GPU helps with rendering, you’re not
allowed to have a GPU that outperforms the CPU. A constraint buried in the procurement
notes says that the Alpha8 CPU isn’t validated to work with the NovaX GPU due to BIOS
issues. And for some reason, the FusionDrive isn’t available unless you’re pairing it
with the ZetaCore.
Despite the abundance of high-performance hardware, you’ll need to select carefully to
stay within these constraints.
Implement: Components: CPUs = {X9, ZetaCore, Alpha8}, GPUs = {QuasarRTX, NovaX, GammaGTX},Storage = {UltraSSD, MegaHDD, FusionDrive}.
Implement: Select exactly one CPU, one GPU, and one storage device.

1 { selected_cpu(C) : cpu(C) } 1.
1 { selected_gpu(G) : gpu(G) } 1.
1 { selected_storage(S) : storage(S) } 1.
Implement: The most expensive selected component must also be the one with the highest performance among selected parts.

selected(X) :- selected_cpu(X).
selected(X) :- selected_gpu(X).
selected(X) :- selected_storage(X).
max_cost(C) :- cost(C, V), V = #max {V1 : cost(C1, V1), selected(C1)}.
max_perf(C) :- perf(C, V), V = #max {V1 : perf(C1, V1), selected(C1)}.
:- selected(C), max_cost(C), not max_perf(C).
Implement: You may not select all three top-performing components.

top_cpu(C) :- cpu(C), perf(C, V), V = #max {V1 : perf(C1, V1), cpu(C1)}.
top_gpu(C) :- gpu(C), perf(C, V), V = #max {V1 : perf(C1, V1), gpu(C1)}.
top_storage(C) :- storage(C), perf(C, V), V = #max {V1 : perf(C1, V1), storage(C1)}.
:- selected_cpu(C), top_cpu(C), selected_gpu(G), top_gpu(G), selected_storage(S), top_storage(S).
Implement: The difference in cost between any two selected components must be ≤ 250.
:- selected(C1), selected(C2), cost(C1, V1), cost(C2, V2), V1 - 250 >= V2.
Implement: The selected GPU must not have higher performance than the selected CPU.
:- selected_cpu(C), selected_gpu(G), perf(C, PC), perf(G, PG), PG > PC.
Implement: Alpha8 is incompatible with NovaX.
Implement: FusionDrive can only be used with ZetaCore.

### Problem Description:
A warehouse bot starts at location A and needs to drop off supplies at two key points
in the facility. The space has five stations labeled A through E. Movement between
stations is constrained to marked paths: A connects to B and D, B to C, and D to E.
It has a total of 6 moves available. Each move takes one time unit. The bot must deliver
to stations C and E once each. It starts at A and can move to any adjacent node at each
timestep.
Implement: Locations: A, B, C, D, E
Implement: The robot can only move between adjacent nodes

1 { at(L, T) : loc(L) } 1 :- time(T).
:- at(L1, T), at(L2, T+1), not edge(L1, L2), not edge(L2, L1), time(T).
Implement: Each delivery location must be visited exactly once
